source: Media playback is not supported on this device The hosts won with a day to spare at Old Trafford to level the series. England made 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared to set up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. "It's an absolute hammering. It's as good a four days of cricket that you could wish for from an England point of view," Vaughan told Test Match Special. England's Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches in Pakistan's first-innings 198 and claimed a wicket in his only over as Pakistan were bowled out for 234 on Monday. "It's great to see him stepping up to number three and playing with the responsibility there," said captain Alastair Cook, who made 105 and 76 not out. "It's as good an innings as I've seen. He's an extraordinary player. He didn't put a foot wrong; he played beautifully." Root, who twice fell to poor strokes in England's 75-run defeat in the first Test, said: "It's a great feeling. "Those two occasions at Lord's were batsman error on my part. I tried to cut that out of my game. It's the most controlled I've played." Coach Trevor Bayliss said: "He went away and did a bit of soul-searching and hard work, came back and did exactly what he said he was going to do." Vaughan: added: "This was his best Test-match innings." Media playback is not supported on this device Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered the bowlers little assistance. "Their spirit was broken," said former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott. "Full marks to England - they got it all together, the quality of the batting, the discipline, their good bowling. "England are in a good place and will win again. They will be too strong for Pakistan. I'll be surprised if they come back." Pakistan play a two-day tour game against Worcestershire at New Road starting on Friday before the third Test at Edgbaston gets under way on 3 August. Media playback is not supported on this device Vaughan said: "England should enjoy the win and have a good party, but I just have a feeling that this series is going to be very, very tight." Of the Pakistan players, only captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq have passed 50 in the first two Tests of the four-match series. "This is a big disappointment for us," said Misbah. "We could have scored around 400 in the first innings - the ball wasn't doing anything much. "We are short of confidence and shot selection really cost us. "These guys are strong characters - mentally strong. I'm hopeful that everybody is hurt and they will really work hard." Media playback is not supported on this device
summary: England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series 1-1. Joe Root, promoted to number three for this series, was named man of the match after scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket in Pakistan's first-innings. England made a total of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Pakistan batted for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second on a pitch that offered little assistance. Pakistan captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment with their performance, particularly their shot selection, and stated that they are short of confidence. The third Test will take place at Edgbaston on 3 August.

summary: England won the match at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They scored 589-8 and 173-1, their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match after scoring 254 and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. England captain Alastair Cook scored 105 and 76 not out. Pakistan batted for only 63 and 70 overs in the first two innings, and their captain Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq are the only players to pass 50 in the series. England coach Trevor Bayliss praised Root's performance, and former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott predicted England's victory in the series. The third Test is scheduled to start on 3 August.

summary:
Here's a concise summary of the passage:

England won the second Test match against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. It was England's second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. England's total scores were 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared. Pakistan struggled, scoring only 198 in their first innings and 234 in the second. Former players and experts praised England's performance, particularly Root's batting. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment in his team's performance, citing a lack of confidence and poor shot selection. The series is expected to remain competitive, with the third Test scheduled at Edgbaston on August 3rd.

summary: England dominated the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, winning by a significant margin and levelling the series. Joe Root was the standout performer, scoring a double century and a quickfire unbeaten half-century, earning him the man of the match award. Root's performance, along with England's overall dominance in batting and bowling, impressed former England players like Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott. Pakistan's struggles with batting consistency and confidence were evident, with only two players crossing the 50-run mark in the series so far. The third Test is scheduled for Edgbaston, with Vaughan predicting a tightly contested series.

summary: England won the cricket series against Pakistan with a significant margin, securing their second largest win in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, performed exceptionally well, scoring 254 in the first innings and 71 in the second, and was named man of the match. Captain Alastair Cook also had a strong performance with scores of 105 and 76 not out. The pitch favored the bowlers, and Pakistan struggled to score, batting for only 63 and 70 overs in the first two innings. Despite the loss, Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed hope that his team would improve. The series is expected to be closely contested, with England leading but facing tough challenges in upcoming matches.

summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage:

England won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, with Joe Root scoring 254 and 71* to be named man of the match. Pakistan were bowled out for 198 and 234, with England's bowlers dominating on a pitch that offered little assistance. The win was England's second biggest over Pakistan in terms of runs, and former England captain Michael Vaughan described it as "an absolute hammering". The series is now level, with two Tests remaining.

Joe Root was named man of the match for his impressive performance, scoring 254 runs in the first innings and 71 in the second. England's bowlers also performed well, bowling Pakistan out for 234 in the second innings. summary: England won the match at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series against Pakistan. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, and coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's improvement after self-reflection. Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs in their innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series. Former players Geoffrey Boycott and Michael Vaughan commented on England's strong performance and Pakistan's broken spirit. Misbah acknowledged Pakistan's poor shot selection and expressed hope for improvement. The third Test will begin on 3 August after Pakistan's tour game against Worcestershire.
